summary: An internal FBI email chain from August 20, 2019, discussing the handling and forensic analysis of external hard drives recovered from a Manhattan residence in connection with the Jeffrey Epstein investigation. The emails indicate the drives were backups of Epstein's computer and laptop, were not encrypted, and their exploitation was a priority due to potential leads on co-conspirators.

persons.name: Supervisory Special Agent/Forensic Examiner Unit Chief Digital Forensics Analysis Unit Operational Technology Division
persons.role: FBI Supervisory Special Agent and Unit Chief
persons.context: Primary recipient and author of emails in the chain, requesting and providing information about the forensic processing of evidence drives from the Epstein investigation.

persons.name: FBI NY CART Coordinator
persons.role: FBI Computer Analysis Response Team Coordinator in New York
persons.context: Provides technical details about the recovered external hard drives, confirming they are backups from Epstein's devices and are not encrypted.

persons.name: IIN Senior Technical Advisor- Digital Systems Science and Technology Branch
persons.context: Forwards a request for clarification about evidence drives recovered from a third party's residence, noting the high-level interest from the Deputy Director (DD) and others due to potential leads on co-conspirators.

persons.name: ADIC
persons.role: Assistant Director in Charge (likely of the New York Field Office)
persons.context: Mentioned as having informed the Deputy Director (DD) about evidence received from a third party's residence in mid to late July.

persons.name: CID
persons.context: Mentioned alongside the ADIC and DD as inquiring about the prioritization of evidence exploitation.

persons.name: EAD
persons.context: Requested clarification on the evidence and asked the Operational Technology Division (OTD) to be on standby for questions.

connections.description: Colleagues within the FBI's forensic and technical divisions communicating about the technical details and processing status of evidence in the Epstein case.

connections.person1: IIN Senior Technical Advisor- Digital Systems Science and Technology Branch
connections.description: The Senior Technical Advisor is relaying the Deputy Director's (DD) specific interest and questions regarding the prioritization of evidence exploitation.
The Assistant Director in Charge (ADIC) is reported to have briefed the Deputy Director (DD) about evidence recovered from a third-party residence.

events.title: Evidence Recovery from Third-Party Residence
events.description: Evidence (external hard drives) was received from a third party's residence. The residence owner turned it over quickly, stating they wanted nothing to do with it after it was placed there by an associate.

events.title: Media Evidence Received by FBI
events.description: Evidence sheets indicate media was formally received by the FBI on this date.

events.title: High-Level FBI Meeting and Email Chain
events.description: A meeting involving the Deputy Director (DD) sparks a chain of urgent emails to clarify and prioritize the forensic exploitation of external hard drives from the Epstein case, due to their potential to identify co-conspirators.
personsInvolved: IIN Senior Technical Advisor- Digital Systems Science and Technology Branch

keyFacts: Two external FireWire 800 hard drives, which were backups of Jeffrey Epstein's computer and laptop, were recovered from a Manhattan residence and were not encrypted.
The drives were subsequently turned over to case agents after being at one point in a third party's residence in mid-to-late July 2019.

The FBI's Deputy Director (DD) took a personal interest in the prioritization of exploiting this media, as it was believed it could lead to the identification of co-conspirators, a matter that also had the attention of the Attorney General (AG).
An initial indication that the drives were encrypted was corrected by the NY CART Coordinator, who confirmed they were not encrypted and would be processed with forensic tool Blacklight.
The email chain highlights high-level, urgent coordination within the FBI in August 2019 regarding digital evidence central to the Epstein investigation.
